{{See also|Flexible Mechanisms#Views on the flexibility mechanisms}} {{essay-like|date=May 2010}} This article is about '''certain views on the [[Kyoto Protocol]]''' to the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]]. A 2007 study by Gupta ''et al.'' assessed the literature on climate change policy which showed no authoritative assessments of the UNFCCC or its Protocol, that assert these agreements have, or will, succeed in fully solving the climate problem.{{citation |at=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch13s13-3-1.html |year=2007 |chapter=13.3.1 Evaluations of existing climate change agreements. |author=Gupta, S. |display-authors=etal}}, in {{harvnb|IPCC TAR WG3|2007}} It was assumed that the UNFCCC or its Protocol would not be changed. The Framework Convention and its Protocol, include provisions for future policy actions to be taken. Some environmentalists have supported the Kyoto Protocol because it is "the only game in town," and possibly because they expect that future emission reduction commitments may demand more stringent emission reductions (Aldy ''et al.''., 2003, p. 9).{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.clipol.2003.09.004 |title=Thirteen Plus One: A Comparison of Global Climate Policy Architectures |date=September 9, 2003 |author=Aldy, J.E.|journal=Climate Policy |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=373–397 |url=http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/publication/17261/thirteen_plus_one.html |accessdate=2010-04-02|display-authors=etal}} Some environmentalists and scientists have criticized the existing commitments for being too weak (Grubb, 2000, p. 5).{{cite journal |date=April 2000 |author=Grubb, M. |title=The Kyoto Protocol: An Economic Appraisal. FEEM Working Paper No. 30 2000 |publisher=SSRN |ssrn=229280 |doi=10.2139/ssrn.229280 |journal= }} On the other hand, many economists think that the commitments are stronger than is justified. Particularly in the US, many economists have also been critical of the failure to include quantified commitments for developing countries (Grubb, 2000, p. 31). ==Commentaries on negotiations== {{See also|Kyoto Protocol#Negotiations}} {| class="wikitable" |+ Level and timing of proposed targets {{harvnb|Depledge|2000|p=45}} ! ''(differentiated)'' || All GHGs || 29 November 1996 |- | UK || 5-10% by 2010 || All GHGs || 16 April 1996 |- | |} The choice of 1990 as the main base year remains in Kyoto, as it does in the original Framework Convention ([[UNFCCC]]). {{harvnb|Grubb|2003|pp=148–149}} The importance of the choice of base year was discussed by Liverman (2008). {{harvnb|Liverman|2008|pp=290–291}} According to Liverman (2008), the idea of using [[greenhouse gas#Cumulative and historical emissions|historical emission]]s as a basis for the Kyoto targets was rejected on the basis that good data was not available prior to 1990. Liverman (2008), however, commented that a 1990 base year favours several powerful interests including the [[UK]], [[Germany]] and [[Russia]]. This is because these countries had high {{CO2}} emissions in 1990. In the UK following 1990, emissions had declined because of a switch from [[coal]] to [[natural gas|gas]] ("[[Dash for Gas]]"), which has lower emissions than coal. This was due to the UK's [[privatization]] of coal mining and its switch to natural gas supported by [[North sea]] reserves. Germany benefited from the 1990 base year because of its reunification between West and East Germany. East Germany's emissions fell dramatically following the collapse of East German industry after the fall of the [[Berlin Wall]]. Germany could therefore take credit for the resultant decline in emissions. According to Liverman (2008), some of the former [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] satellites wanted a base year to reflect their highest emissions prior to their industrial collapse. A high emissions baseline was an advantage for countries whose emissions had subsequently fallen due to economic collapse. On the other hand, some of the former Soviet countries regard their emissions surplus as compensation for the trauma of economic restructuring. {{harvnb|Carbon Trust|2009|p=25}} [[Japan]] promoted the idea of flexible baselines, and favoured a base year of 1995 for [[hydrofluorocarbons|HFC]]s. Their HFC emissions had grown in the early 1990s as a substitute for [[chlorofluorocarbons|CFC]]s banned in the [[Montreal Protocol]]. Liverman (2008) argued that countries, such as the US, made suggestions during negotiations in order to lower their responsibility to cut emissions. These suggestions included the inclusion of [[carbon sink]]s (the carbon absorbed annually by [[forest]]s and other land cover) and having net current emissions as the basis for responsibility, rather than historical emissions. Another perspective on negotiations was provided by Grubb (2003). The final days of negotiation of the Protocol saw a clash between the EU and the US and Japan. {{harvnb|Grubb|2003|p=149}} The EU aimed for flat-rate reductions in the range of 10–15% below 1990 levels, while the US and Japan supported reductions of 0–5%.see [[Kyoto Protocol#Negotiations]] for more details on the original targets proposed by countries Countries that had supported differentiation of targets between countries had different ideas on how it should be calculated, and many different indicators were proposed, e.g., targets that were related to [[GDP]], [[energy intensity]] (energy use per unit of economic output), and so on. {{harvnb|Grubb|2003|p=151}} According to Grubb (2003), the only common theme of these indicators was that each proposal suited the interests of the country making the proposal. Aldy ''et al.'' (2003) {{harvnb|Aldy|Barrett|Stavins|2003|p=7}} commented on the Kyoto targets and how they related to economic growth. Considering the growth of some economies and the collapse of others since 1990, the range of implicit targets is much greater than that suggested by the Kyoto targets. According to Aldy ''et al.'' (2003), the US faced a cut of about 30% below "[[Economics of climate change mitigation#Baselines|business-as-usual]]" (BAU) emissions (i.e., projected emissions in the absence of measures to limit emissions), which is more stringent than that implied by its Kyoto target (a 7% reduction in emissions compared to 1990 levels). {{harvnb|Liverman|2008|p=292}} This contrasts with Russia and other Kyoto "economies in transition" (EITs), who, according to Aldy ''et al.'' (2003), faced Kyoto targets that allowed substantial increases in their emissions above BAU. Grubb (2003), however, commented that the US, having [[Greenhouse gas#Regional and national attribution of emissions|per-capita emissions]] twice that of most other [[OECD]] countries, was vulnerable to the suggestion that it had huge potential for making reductions. From this viewpoint, the US was obliged to cut emissions back more than other countries. Grubb (2003) {{harvnb|Grubb|2003|pp=162–163}} also commented that for two or three years after the Kyoto agreement, the usual economic perspective was that emissions from the EITs would rise sharply as their economies recovered. In reality, however, emissions of the EITs failed to grow as many models had predicted. In August 2012, in a speech given at his alma mater, Todd Stern — the US Climate Change envoy — expressed the challenges of the UNFCCC process as follows, “Climate change is not a conventional environmental issue...It implicates virtually every aspect of a state’s economy, so it makes countries nervous about growth and development. This is an economic issue every bit as it is an environmental one.” He went on to explain that the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change is a multilateral body concerned with climate change and can be an inefficient system for enacting international policy. Because the framework system includes over 190 countries and because negotiations are governed by consensus, small groups of countries can often block progress.{{cite web |title="Voices" speaker talks climate change |url=http://thedartmouth.com/2012/08/03/news/climate |publisher=The Dartmouth |accessdate=29 November 2012}} ==General comments== Baylis ''et al.'' (2011) Baylis, John, Steve Smith, and Patricia Owens. The Globalization of World Politics. 5th ed. Oxford: 2011. p.358. argued that a successful international climate policy would require additional emission reductions from developing countries such as China and India. ==Support== In September 2012 the Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency and the European Commission's Joint Research Centre released a detailed study which showed that the 37 main Kyoto nations plus the U.S. (which did not ratify the treaty) have emitted 7.5 per cent less carbon dioxide into the atmosphere in 2010 than in 1990.{{cite web |url= http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2011/12/11/f-vp-sheppard-analysis-durban-kyoto.html |title=Farewell Kyoto Protocol, you did your job |first= Roger |last=Sheppard |work=CBC News |date= December 11, 2012 |accessdate=December 19, 2012}} The [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush Administration's]] rejection of Kyoto could have led to its failure (Grubb, 2002, p. 140).{{cite web |year = 2002 |title = Britannia waives the rules - The UK, the EU and climate change |publisher = New Economy |author = Grubb, M. |url = http://www.econ.cam.ac.uk/rstaff/grubb/publications/GA08.pdf |pages = 139–142 |accessdate = 2010-04-02 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110717152216/http://www.econ.cam.ac.uk/rstaff/grubb/publications/GA08.pdf |archive-date = 2011-07-17 |dead-url = yes |df = }} In the view of Grubb (2002), the EU's subsequent decision to support the Protocol was key. Environmental organization the [[Environmental Defense Fund]] have been supportive of the Protocol (EDF, 2005).{{cite web |title=COP-11: Celebrating Kyoto's Entry into Force |date=November 14, 2005 |author=EDF |url=http://www.edf.org/article.cfm?contentID=4865 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713014920/http://www.edf.org/article.cfm?contentID=4865 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 13, 2007 |publisher=Environmental Defense Fund website |accessdate=2010-04-03}} Jonathan Pershing, director of the Climate and Energy Program at the [[World Resources Institute]], stated that the Protocol "makes it clear that the world takes the global warming problem seriously" (Pershing, 2005).{{cite web |title=The Climate of a Post-Kyoto World |author=Pershing, J. |publisher=World Resources Institute website |url=http://www.wri.org/stories/2005/03/the-climate-a-post-kyoto-world |date=March 28, 2005 |accessdate=2010-04-03}} The [[United Nations]] has issued reports favoring the Kyoto Protocol.{{cite web|title=UNFCCC and the Kyoto Protocol|url=https://www.un.org/wcm/content/site/climatechange/pages/gateway/the-negotiations/the-un-climate-change-convention-and-the-kyoto-protocol|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=14 June 2012}} Supporters of Kyoto stated it is a first step towards meeting the ultimate objective of the UNFCCC, which is to prevent dangerous climate change.{{cite web |last=Wigley |first=Tom |title=The effect of the Kyoto Protocol on global warming |date=Spring 2006 |url=http://www2.ucar.edu/news/record/effect-kyoto-protocol-global-warming |accessdate=2006-10-30 }}{{cite journal |last=Wigley |first=Tom |title= The Kyoto Protocol: CO2, CH4, and climate implications |journal=Geophys. Res. Lett. |volume=25 |issue=13 |page= 2285 |url=http://www.agu.org/pubs/abs/gl/98GL01855/98GL01855.html |accessdate=4 March 2006 |doi=10.1029/98GL01855 |year=1998 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050208072312/http://www.agu.org/pubs/abs/gl/98GL01855/98GL01855.html |archivedate = 8 February 2005 |bibcode = 1998GeoRL..25.2285W }} They state that the Protocol will be revised in order to meet this objective, as is required by UNFCCC Article 4.2(d).{{cite web |title=Article 4 |work=The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change |url=http://unfccc.int/essential_background/convention/background/items/1362.php |accessdate=15 November 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110124034306/https://unfccc.int/essential_background/convention/background/items/1362.php |archivedate=January 24, 2011 }} In 2001, sixteen national science the [[Royal Society of New Zealand|Academy Council of the Royal Society of New Zealand]], the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]], and the [[Royal Society]] (UK) stated that ratification of the |author=Joint academies' statement |date=May 18, 2001 |journal=Science |volume=292 |issue=5520 |page=1261 |doi=10.1126/science.292.5520.1261 |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/short/292/5520/1261 |accessdate=2010-04-03}} In 2005, the national science academies of the G8 nations and Brazil, China and IndiaAcademia Brasiliera de Ciências (Brazil), Royal Society of Canada, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Académie des Sciences (France), Deutsche Akademie der Naturforscher Leopoldina (Germany) Indian National Science Academy, Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei (Italy), Science Council of Japan, [[Russian Academy of Sciences]], Royal Society (United Kingdom), [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] (United States of America) made a statement where they "urged" all nations to "take prompt action to reduce the causes of climate change, adapt to its impacts and ensure that the issue is included in all relevant national and international strategies." They stated that these actions should be taken in line with UNFCCC principles.{{cite web |date=June 7, 2005 |title=Global response to climate change |author=Joint science academies’ statement |url=http://royalsociety.org/Joint-science-academies-statement-Global-response-to-climate-change/ |publisher=UK Royal Society website |accessdate=2010-04-03}} An international day of action was planned for 3 December 2005, to coincide with the Meeting of the Parties in Montreal. A group of major Canadian corporations also called for urgent action regarding climate change, and have suggested that Kyoto is only a first step.{{cite news | publisher = CBC | title=Business leaders call for climate change action |date=2005-11-17 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ndB1r89m?url=http://www.cbc.ca/money/story/2005/11/17/kyotobiz-051117.html |archivedate=2010-02-18 |url = http://www.cbc.ca/money/story/2005/11/17/kyotobiz-051117.html }} ==Criticism== {{Main|Criticism of the Kyoto Protocol}} Some argue the protocol does not go far enough to curb greenhouse emissionsEkardt/von Hövel, Carbon & Climate Law Review 2009, p. 102-114 ([[Niue]], The [[Cook Islands]], and [[Nauru]] added notes to this effect when signing the protocol).{{cite web| url=http://unfccc.int/files/essential_background/kyoto_protocol/application/pdf/kpstats.pdf |publisher=UNFCCC| title= Kyoto protocol status(pdf)| accessdate=2006-11-07|format=PDF}} Some [[Environmental economics|environmental economists]] have been critical of the Kyoto Protocol.{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4504298 |publisher=NPR |title=An Economist's View of the Kyoto Climate Treaty |first=Robert O. |last= Mendelsohn |date=2005-02-18 |accessdate=2006-11-07}}{{cite news |url=http://www.econ.uiuc.edu/~seppala/econ102/kyoto.html |newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]]| title=Environmental Economists Debate Merit of U.S.'s Kyoto Withdrawal |first=Jon E. |last= Hilsenrath |date= 2001-08-07 |accessdate=2006-11-07}}{{cite journal |first=Gwyn |last=Prins |first2=Steve |last2=Rayner |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v449/n7165/full/449973a.html |title=Time to ditch Kyoto |journal=Nature |volume=449 |pages=973–975 |doi=10.1038/449973a |date=2007-10-25 |accessdate=2009-05-21 |pmid=17960215 |issue=7165|bibcode = 2007Natur.449..973P }} Many{{Who|date=March 2010}} see the costs of the Kyoto Protocol as outweighing the benefits, some believing the standards which Kyoto sets to be too optimistic, others seeing a highly inequitable and inefficient agreement which would do little to curb greenhouse gas emissions.{{cite web |title=The Impact of the Kyoto Protocol on U.S. Economic Growth and Projected Budget Surpluses |url=http://www.accf.org/publications/testimonies/test-impactkyoto-march25-1999.html |accessdate=2005-11-15 |archiveurl = http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20041216232625/http://www.accf.org/publications/testimonies/test-impactkyoto-march25-1999.html |archivedate = 2004-12-16}}{{Full citation needed|date=March 2010}} Stavins (2005) criticized the Protocol as doing "too little, too fast," in that it asks for excessively costly short-term reductions in emissions, without determining what should be done over longer timeframes (Stern 2007, p. 478). Over longer timeframes, there is more flexibility to make reductions in line with normal cycles of capital stock replacement. At the time of the Protocol's first commitment period, in 1997, it provided a 15-year window for action. The Protocol does not provide any guidance or formulae linking the action required in the first commitment period to an overall global quantity constraint on emissions, or to a long-term timetable for emissions reductions. In the view of Stern (2007), this lack of a long-term goal, coupled with problems over incentives to comply with emission reduction commitments, prevented the Protocol from providing a credible signal for governments and businesses to make long-term investments. Some have heavily criticized the Protocol for only setting emission reductions for rich countries, while not setting such commitments for the fast-growing emerging economies, e.g., China and India (Stern 2007, p. 478). Australia (under Prime Minister [[John Howard]]) and the US subsequently did not ratify the Protocol, although Australia has since ratified the treaty. A number of other countries have not taken strong steps to implement it. Developing countries did take on obligations under the Protocol, but these were unquantified and allowed climate change to be addressed as part of wider national policies on sustainable development. In his 2009 book ("[[Storms of my Grandchildren]]") and in an open letter to US President Obama, climate scientist [[James E. Hansen|James Hansen]] criticized the Kyoto Protocol for being ineffective.{{cite web |first=Keith |last=Kloor |title=The Eye of the Storm |url=http://www.nature.com/climate/2009/0912/full/climate.2009.124.html |publisher=Nature Reports Climate Change |date=2009-11-26 |accessdate=2009-12-11}}{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article6941974.ece |title=Climate scientist James Hansen hopes summit will fail |first=James |last=Bone |newspaper=Times Online |date=2009-12-03}}{{cite web |last=Greenberg |first=Nell |url=http://www.grist.org/article/2009-09-28-james-hansen-on-obama-climate-legislation-and-coal/ |title=James Hansen on Obama, climate legislation, and the scourge of coal |publisher=Grist |date=2009-09-28 |accessdate=2010-01-27}}{{cite web |first=James |last=Hansen |url=http://www.columbia.edu/~jeh1/mailings/20081229_DearMichelleAndBarack.pdf |title=Letter to Obama |accessdate=2009-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126201600/http://www.columbia.edu/~jeh1/mailings/20081229_DearMichelleAndBarack.pdf |archivedate=January 26, 2009 }}{{cite web |first=James |last=Hansen |title=Tell Barack Obama the Truth |url=http://www.columbia.edu/~jeh1/mailings/20081229_Obama_revised.pdf |accessdate=2009-12-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106094410/http://www.columbia.edu/~jeh1/mailings/20081229_Obama_revised.pdf |archivedate=January 6, 2009 }} In May 2010 [[the Hartwell Paper]] was published by the [[London School of Economics]] in collaboration with the [[University of Oxford]].{{cite web|url=http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/27939/1/HartwellPaper_English_version.pdf|title=The Hartwell Paper - A new direction for climate policy after the crash of 2009|author=Prins, Gwyn et. al |publisher=[[London School of Economics]] |date=May 2010|accessdate=2010-05-12}} This paper was written by 14 academics from various disciplines in the sciences and humanities, and also some policies thinkers, and they argued that after the failure of the 2009 [[Copenhagen Climate Summit]], the Kyoto Protocol crashed and they claimed that it "''has failed to produce any discernable real world reductions in emissions of greenhouse gases in fifteen years.''"{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/8673828.stm|title=After the crash - a new direction for climate policy|publisher=[[BBC News]]|author=Mike Hulme|date=2010-05-11|accessdate=2010-05-12}} They argued that this failure opened an opportunity to set climate policy free from Kyoto and the paper advocates a controversial and piecemeal approach to [[Low-carbon economy|decarbonization]] of the global economy.{{cite news|url=http://dotearth.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/05/11/a-tough-observer-of-climate-prescriptions/?ref=earth|title=A Tough Observer of Climate Prescriptions|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|author=Andrew C. Revkin|date=2010-05-11|accessdate=2010-05-12}} The Hartwell paper proposes that ''"the organising principle of our effort should be the raising up of human dignity via three overarching objectives: ensuring energy access for all; ensuring that we develop in a manner that does not undermine the essential functioning of the Earth system; ensuring that our societies are adequately equipped to withstand the risks and dangers that come from all the vagaries of climate, whatever their cause may be."''{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/world/international/displaystory.cfm?story_id=16099521|title=Oblique strategies|publisher=[[The Economist]]|date=2010-05-11|accessdate=2010-05-12}}{{cite news|url=http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2010/05/do-you-heart-the-hartwell-paper.html |title=Do You Heart 'The Hartwell Paper'? |publisher=[[Science (journal)|Science Insider]] |date=2010-05-12 |accessdate=2010-05-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528030007/http://news.sciencemag.org/scienceinsider/2010/05/do-you-heart-the-hartwell-paper.html |archivedate=May 28, 2010 }} The overall umbrella and processes of the UNFCCC and the Kyoto Protocol have been criticized for not having achieved the stated goals of reducing the emission of [[carbon dioxide]] (the primary culprit blamed for rising global temperatures of the 21st century).{{cite web|title=The Kyoto Protocol: Hot air|url=http://www.nature.com/news/the-kyoto-protocol-hot-air-1.11882|work=Nature|accessdate=29 November 2012}} ==Economics== {{See also|Economics of climate change mitigation#Kyoto Protocol}} The flexibility mechanisms that are defined in the Protocol could allow the Annex B countries to meet their emission reduction commitments at a significantly reduced cost (Bashmakov ''et al.''., 2001, p. 402;{{cite web |year=2001 |title=Policies, Measures, and Instruments. Chapter 6 in: Climate Change 2001: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Third Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (B. Metz ''et al''. Eds.) |publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A. |author=Bashmakov, I.|url=http://www.grida.no/publications/other/ipcc_tar/ |accessdate=2009-05-20|display-authors=etal}} Goulder and Pizer, 2006, p. 12).{{cite web |date=June 2006 |title=RFF DP 06-06: The Economics of Climate Change |author=Goulder, L.H. and W.A. Pizer |publisher=Resources for the Future, 1616 P St. NW, Washington, DC, USA |url=http://www.rff.org/documents/RFF-DP-06-06.pdf}} Actual costs will be determined by how individual countries decide to meet their commitments. This can involve the use of the international flexibility mechanisms, but domestic policies can also contribute, such as raising taxes on gasoline or regulatory fines for major polluters. The Kyoto Protocol was designed to be efficient and equitable (Toth ''et al.''., 2001, p. 660),{{cite web |year=2001 |title=Decision-making Frameworks. In: Climate Change 2001: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Third Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (B. Metz ''et al''. Eds.) |publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A. |author=Toth, F.L.|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/publications_and_data_reports.htm |accessdate=2010-01-10|display-authors=etal}} but it has been subject to criticism (Stern, 2007, p. 478).{{cite web |year=2007 |title=Creating a Global Price for Carbon. In: Stern Review on the Economics of Climate Change (pre-publication edition) |author=Stern, N. |publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A. |url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/sternreview_index.htm |accessdate=2010-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5nCeyEYJr?url=http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/sternreview_index.htm |archivedate=January 31, 2010 }} Nordhaus (2001) drew attention to the inefficiencies of the Kyoto Protocol's flexibility mechanisms.{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.1065007 |date=9 November 2001 |author=Nordhaus, W.D. |journal=Science |title=Global Warming Economics |pages=1283–1284 |issue=5545 |volume=294 |url=http://nordhaus.econ.yale.edu/nordhaus_science_110901.pdf |accessdate=2010-03-26 |pmid=11701912}} Nordhaus explained that meeting the emission reduction commitments specified in the Kyoto-Bonn Accord, using the quantity-type instruments as defined in the Protocol, would be less efficient compared to a situation where price-type instruments were used, e.g., a harmonized [[carbon tax]] (comparisons of quantity-type and price-type instruments are included in the [[carbon tax#Carbon taxes compared to cap-and-trade|carbon tax]] and [[emissions trading#Prices versus quantities, and the safety valve|emissions trading]] articles). Nordhaus suggested that given the Protocol's large costs and small benefits, it might be better for it to be redesigned along the lines of a global carbon tax. Other economists such as [[Gwyn Prins]] and [[Steve Rayner]], think an entirely different approach needs to be followed than suggested by the Kyoto Protocol.{{cite web |url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/collections/pressAndInformationOffice/newsAndEvents/archives/2007/KyotoNatureArticle.htm |title=Radical rethinking of approach needed says Steve Rayner and Gwyn Prins |publisher=Lse.ac.uk |date=n.d. |accessdate=2009-05-21}} The issue of the efficient (or "optimal") path for greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions depends on various assumptions (Klein ''et al.''., 2007).{{cite web |year=2007 |title=18.4.1 Trade-offs and synergies in global-scale analysis. In (book chapter): Inter-relationships between adaptation and mitigation. In (book): Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability. Contribution of Working Group II to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (M.L. Parry ''et al''. Eds.) |publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: IPCC website |author=Klein, R.J.T.|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch18s18-4-1.html |accessdate=2010-03-28|display-authors=etal}} Some of these assumptions, e.g., aggregating impacts across regions and over time, rely on value judgements (Azar, 1998;{{cite journal |doi = 10.1023/A:1008235326513 |year = 1998 |title = Are Optimal CO2 Emissions Really Optimal? Four Critical Issues for Economists in the Greenhouse |author = Azar, C. |journal = Environmental and Resource Economics |volume = 11 |issue = 3–4 |pages = 301–315 |url = http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/d/azar_1998_four_crucial_issues.pdf |accessdate = 2009-01-10 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120316140445/http://www.hm-treasury.gov.uk/d/azar_1998_four_crucial_issues.pdf |archive-date = 2012-03-16 |dead-url = yes |df = }} Fisher ''et al.''., 2007).{{cite web |year=2007 |title=3.5.3.3 Cost-benefit analysis, damage cost estimates and social costs of carbon. In (book chapter): Issues related to mitigation in the long term context. In (book): Climate Change 2007: Mitigation. Contribution of Working Group III to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (B. Metz ''et al''. Eds.) |publisher=Print version: Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, U.K., and New York, N.Y., U.S.A.. This version: IPCC website |author=Fisher, B.S.|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch3s3-5-3-3.html |accessdate=2010-03-28|display-authors=etal}} In Nordhaus's analysis, the implied emissions path of the Kyoto-Bonn Accord is more aggressive than that suggested in his analysis (Klein ''et al.''., 2007). In other words, the efficient abatement path for emissions in Nordhaus's analysis, suggests more gradual near-term emissions abatement than that implied by Kyoto's emission reduction commitments. This is a common finding of economic cost-benefit analysis, and is driven by low estimates of [[margin (economics)|marginal]] (or incremental) climate change damages (the [[carbon tax#Social cost of carbon|social cost of carbon]]). ==U.S. History with the Protocol== {{See also|Kyoto Protocol and government action#United States}} '''Clinton Administration''' Vice President Al Gore was a main participant in putting the Kyoto Protocol together in 1997. President Bill Clinton signed the agreement in 1997, but the US Senate refused to ratify it, citing potential damage to the US economy required by compliance. The Senate also balked at the agreement because it excluded certain developing countries, including India and China, from having to comply with new emissions standards.{{cite news |url=http://usliberals.about.com/od/environmentalconcerns/p/KyotoProtocol.htm |title=George Bush Refuses to Sign Kyoto Protocol to Stem Global Warming |newspaper=About.com |publisher=The New York Times Company |author=Deborah White |year=2010 |accessdate=2010-11-06 }} '''Bush administration''' Similar objections to the Kyoto Protocol were why the Bush administration refused to sign. They argued the division between Annex 1 and developing countries was unfair, and that both countries needed to reduce their emissions unilaterally. President George W. Bush claimed that the cost of following the Protocols requirements will stress the economy. Al Gore accused Bush of showing the world "a stunning display of moral cowardice." "Kyoto's ability to survive the near-fatal attacks of the Bush administration is testimony to the urgency of the climate problem." Worldwatch Institute Laurie David, Natural Resources Defense Council said, "As the world celebrates the global warming pact's debut, Bush continues to pander to the energy industry." '''Obama Administration''' President Obama was elected under widespread belief that shortly after arriving in office he would take swift and decisive action to join the world in reducing GHG emissions and therefore helping battle global climate change. According to ''The American'', “Obama was widely expected to quickly pass a Kyoto-style domestic cap-and-trade program for greenhouse gases, positioning America to take the moral high ground in Copenhagen, thus luring (or compelling) China and India to accept emissions targets.".{{cite news |url = http://www.american.com/archive/2009/november/the-quiet-yet-historic-death-of-the-kyoto-protoco |title = The Quiet Death of the Kyoto Protocol |newspaper = The American |publisher = American Enterprise Institute |first = Samuel |last = Thernstrom |date = 2009-11-05 |accessdate = 2011-01-12 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20101026234940/http://american.com/archive/2009/november/the-quiet-yet-historic-death-of-the-kyoto-protoco/ |archive-date = 2010-10-26 |dead-url = yes |df = }} Signing the Kyoto protocol seemed like the logical first step so it came as a surprise when he rejected the Kyoto protocol for reasons similar to those of former president Bush. According to ''The American'', “the treaty’s fundamental flaws were well understood: It set very ambitious—and costly—targets for the United States while allowing emissions from the developing world to continue to rise unchecked. (And indeed today, despite Kyoto’s ratification, China has become the world’s leading emitter of greenhouse gases.) Americans don’t mind contributing to a solution, but Kyoto asked a lot of sacrifice for little reward.”. President Obama was also expected to represent the U.S in Copenhagen and negotiate terms for the extension of the Kyoto Protocol past 2012. Yet instead of the U.S. contributing to the development and signing of a Kyoto-like treaty, the U.S. is suggesting extreme modifications of the Kyoto emission management system and precipitating intense debates and clashes over the treaty which will follow Kyoto. Many countries fear these new treaty additions will paralyze negotiations and stop many of the countries currently under the Kyoto Protocol from re-signing as well as stop new countries, like China and India, from signing. “the Obama administration’s proposals could undermine a new global treaty and weaken the world’s ability to stave off the worst effects of climate change.”{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2009/sep/15/europe-us-copenhagen | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=David | last=Adam | title=US planning to weaken Copenhagen climate deal, Europe warns | date=2009-09-15}} Many people feel that the combination of the U.S not signing the Kyoto Protocol (ensuring it will run out in 2012) and the U.S. attempt to change almost the entire architecture of the Kyoto Protocol in Copenhagen means the end of the Kyoto Protocol as we know it and perhaps a new global climate treaty. “If Kyoto is scrapped, it could take several years to negotiate a replacement framework, a delay that could strike a terminal blow at efforts to [[Avoiding dangerous climate change|prevent dangerous climate change]]. In Europe we want to build on Kyoto, but the US proposal would in effect kill it off. If we have to start from scratch then it all takes time. It could be 2015 or 2016 before something is in place, who knows." ==Objections to the Kyoto Protocol and U.S refusal to sign== The [[Kyoto Protocol]] was a huge leap forward towards an intergovernmental united strategy to reduce GHG’s emissions globally. But it wasn’t without its objections. Some of the main criticisms were against categorizing different countries into annexes, with each annex having its own responsibility for emission reductions based on historic GHG emissions and, therefore, historic contribution to global climate change. “Some of the criticism of the Protocol has been based on the idea of climate justice."{{cite journal |year=2008 |title=Conventions of climate change: constructions of danger and the dispossession of the atmosphere |doi=10.1016/j.jhg.2008.08.008 |author=Liverman, D.M. |journal=Journal of Historical Geography |url=http://archserve.id.ucsb.edu/courses/id-moodle/moodledata/1413/readings/Liverman.pdf|accessdate=2009-08-08 |volume=35 |issue=2 |pages=279}} This has particularly centered on the balance between the low emissions and high vulnerability of the developing world to climate change, compared to high emissions in the developed world.” Other objections were the use of carbon off-sets as a method for a country to reduce its carbon emissions. Although it can be beneficial to balance out one GHG emission by implementing an equal carbon offset, it still doesn’t completely eliminate the original carbon emission and therefore ultimately reduce the amount of GHG’s in the atmosphere.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==References== *{{citation |title=Thirteen Plus One: A Comparison of Global Climate Policy Architectures |date=9 September 2003 |last=Aldy | first=J.E. | last2=Barrett | first2=S. | last3=Stavins | first3=R.N. |journal=Climate Policy |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=373–397 |url=http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/publication/17261/thirteen_plus_one.html |doi=10.1016/j.clipol.2003.09.004}} *{{citation |date=March 2009 |title=Global Carbon Mechanisms: Emerging lessons and implications (CTC748) |author=Carbon Trust |url=http://www.carbontrust.com/resources/reports/advice/global-carbon-mechanisms |publisher=Carbon Trust | location=London, UK }} *{{Citation |date=25 November 2000 |title=United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Technical paper: Tracing the Origins of the Kyoto Protocol: An Article-by-Article Textual History |publisher=UNFCCC |last=Depledge | first=J. |url=http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/tp/tp0200.pdf |format=PDF }} *{{citation |date = December 2001 |last = Dessai |first = S. |title = Tyndall Centre Working Paper 12: The climate regime from The Hague to Marrakech: Saving or sinking the Kyoto Protocol? |url = http://www.tyndall.ac.uk/content/climate-regime-hague-marrakech-saving-or-sinking-kyoto-protocol |publisher = Tyndall Centre |location = Norwich, UK |access-date = 2012-12-12 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121031094826/http://www.tyndall.ac.uk/content/climate-regime-hague-marrakech-saving-or-sinking-kyoto-protocol |archive-date = 2012-10-31 |dead-url = yes |df = }} *{{citation | author=G-77 | date=22 November 2011 | url=http://g77.org/doc/members.html | title=The Group of 77 - Member States | publisher=The Group of 77 | accessdate=22 October 2012 }} *{{citation |title = The Economics of the Kyoto Protocol |last = Grubb |first = M. |date = July–September 2003 |journal = World Economics |volume = 4 |issue = 3 |url = http://www.econ.cam.ac.uk/rstaff/grubb/publications/J36.pdf |format = PDF |access-date = 2010-03-25 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110717152152/http://www.econ.cam.ac.uk/rstaff/grubb/publications/J36.pdf |archive-date = 2011-07-17 |dead-url = yes |df = }} *{{citation |year = 2008 |title = Conventions of climate change: constructions of danger and the dispossession of the atmosphere |doi = 10.1016/j.jhg.2008.08.008 |last = Liverman |first = D.M. |journal = Journal of Historical Geography |url = http://www.environment.arizona.edu/files/env/profiles/liverman/liverman-2009-jhg.pdf |format = PDF |volume = 35 |issue = 2 |access-date = 2011-05-10 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140912161138/http://www.environment.arizona.edu/files/env/profiles/liverman/liverman-2009-jhg.pdf |archive-date = 2014-09-12 |dead-url = yes |df = }} {{Global warming}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Views On The Kyoto Protocol}} [[Category:Carbon dioxide]] [[Category:Carbon finance]] [[Category:United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]]

[[Škoda Octavia]] Mk2 | sp = uk }} The '''Volkswagen Golf Mk6''' (or VW ''Typ 5K or MK VI'') is a [[compact car]], the sixth generation of the [[Volkswagen Golf]] and the successor to the [[Volkswagen Golf Mk5]]. It was unveiled at the [[Paris Auto Show]] in October 2008. [[Volkswagen]] released pictures and information on 6 August 2008, prior to the official unveiling. The vehicle was released to the [[Europe]]an market in the winter of 2008. Major investments have been made in production efficiency, with a claimed productivity improvement at launch of nearly 20% in comparison with the previous model, and further gains planned for the next twelve months.{{cite book |last= |first= |authorlink= |author=Alexander Bloch u. Hans-Dieter Seufert (Bilder) |title= Auto Motor und Sport Heft 20 Seite 26|year= 2008 |publisher= |location= Stuttgart |id=}} Although billed as the Mk6, the new model was in effect a thoroughly re-engineered facelift of the previous model. In January 2013, it was superseded by the [[Volkswagen Golf Mk7]]. ==Design== Like its predecessor, the Mk6 Golf is based on the [[Volkswagen Group A platform#A5|Volkswagen Group A5 (PQ35) platform]]. Effectively it is a reskin of the Mk5 rather than an all-new design, it was developed with engineering improvements to shorten the previous model's excessive assembly time, and answered criticisms of that model's cheapened interior quality compared to that of the 1999.5 Mk4. ==Specifications== ===Equipment=== Improvements in equipment level on the domestic market Golfs include, for the first time in a Golf, the inclusion of air conditioning as standard.(2008) Auto Motor und Sport Heft 20 Seite 26 Additionally, dual-zone climate control is included in the Autobahn trim for North America.{{cite web|url=http://www.fathersandsonsvwnews.com/articles/10CoolThingsAboutthe2012VolkswagenGTI/ |title=10 Cool Things About the 2012 Volkswagen GTI |publisher=FathersandSonsVWnews.com |accessdate=29 October 2012}} ===Engines=== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; font-size:95%;" |- !colspan=7|Petrol engine |- ! GTI version features the [[list of Volkswagen Group petrol engines#2.0 TFSI 132-155kW|2.0-litre TSI]]. ===Safety=== With safety features such as seven standard [[airbag]]s, (up to nine in Europe, up to eight in the US) and standard [[electronic stability control|Electronic Stability Programme]] (ESP), the Golf Mk6 has scored 36 out of 37 possible points for occupant protection, giving it a five-star rating by the [[EuroNCAP|Euro NCAP]] crash test agency. It was one of the safest vehicles in its class at the time of its release.{{cite web|url=http://www.ausmotive.com/2008/11/04/volkswagen-earns-five-star-crash-rating.html |title=Volkswagen Golf VI earns five-star crash rating |publisher=AUSmotive.com |date=4 November 2008 |accessdate=1 November 2010}} ==Cabriolet== {{Advert|section|date=May 2012}} [[File:VW Golf VI Cabriolet 1.4 TSI Deeppurple Heck.JPG|thumb|right|Cabriolet]] The new Volkswagen Golf Cabriolet was presented at the 2011 [[Geneva International Motor Show]]. The four-seater has a soft top with an electro-hydraulic drive that opens the Golf's top in 9.5 seconds. The top can also be opened or closed during driving at speeds of up to {{Convert|30|km/h|mi/h|0|abbr=on}}. After a nine years without a convertible Golf, it was the first Cabriolet model under the Golf family since 2002. The new VW Golf Cabriolet's styling follows that of its hard-top three-door counterpart, but it differs somewhat with a new rear section, lower profile roof line and more swept-back angle of its front windscreen frame. Bi-xenon headlights are an option. Unlike the regular Golf, the Cabriolet has LED rear lights, which are only available for the R and GTI versions of the hardtop. Safety features include the automatically deploying roll-over bar, front airbags, side head/thorax airbags, knee airbag for the driver and ESP. There are six turbocharged direct-injection engines whose power outputs range from {{Convert|77|kW|PS hp|0|abbr=on}} to {{Convert|155|kW|PS hp|0|abbr=on}}. Four of the petrol engines (TSI) and one diesel (TDI) are available with the DSG dual-clutch gearbox; while three of the engines are available with energy-saving BlueMotion Technology. In February 2012, Volkswagen announced that they would build a Cabriolet version of the GTI, powered by a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine.{{cite web|title=Geneva preview: 2012 Volkswagen Golf GTI Cabriolet|url=http://www.leftlanenews.com/volkswagen-gti-cabriolet-2012.html|publisher=Left Lane News|accessdate=29 February 2012}} As of October 2016, VW announced that the Golf cabriolet will no longer be sold in the U.K. due to financial reasons. http://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/new-cars/volkswagen-golf-cabriolet-axed-uk-line ==Variant== [[File:2013 Volkswagen Golf (5K MY13.5) 90TSI Trendline station wagon (2015-06-18) 02.jpg|thumb|right|Variant]] {{See also|Volkswagen Golf Variant}} A facelifted variant Mk5 Golf Variant model was introduced in 2009 as the Mk6, despite carrying the front fascia, interior styling, and the drive line from the new Golf, the underpinnings are based on its fifth-generation predecessor. It is sold in the US as the Jetta SportWagen, in Mexico and Canada as the Golf Wagon and in South America as the Jetta Variant or Vento Variant. {{clear}} ==Golf Plus== In December 2008, a facelifted version of the Golf Plus was revealed at the [[Bologna Motor Show]],http://www.autoblog.com/2008/12/03/vw-golf-plus-officially-debuts-in-bologna/ featuring a revised front end, similar to the Golf Mk6, but still largely retaining the design of the rear end and the interior of the Mk5 based vehicle.http://www.autoevolution.com/volkswagen/golf-plus/ In 2014 the Golf Plus was replaced by the [[Volkswagen Group MQB platform|MQB]] based Golf Sportsvan, which was originally shown as the Sportvan concept. VW CrossGolf – Frontansicht, 19. Mai 2011, Velbert.jpg|VW CrossGolf (2006–2010) VW CrossGolf – Heckansicht, 19. Mai 2011, Velbert.jpg|Rear VW CrossGolf Facelift.JPG|VW CrossGolf (2010–2014) VW CrossGolf Facelift Heck.JPG|Rear ==Twin Drive== {{Update|date=November 2015}} Volkswagen CEO [[Martin Winterkorn]] announced Golf Twin Drive plug-in hybrid concept based on Mk5 Golf, which uses 2.0 L {{Convert|122|hp|kW|order=flip|abbr=on}} [[inline-four engine|I4]] turbodiesel and {{Convert|82|hp|kW|order=flip|abbr=on}} electric motor with lithium-ion batteries. The car can run about 50 kilometres on battery power.{{cite web|last=Neff |first=John |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2008/06/26/vw-to-fleet-test-twin-drive-golf-plug-in-hybrid-concept-in-2010/ |title=VW to fleet test Twin Drive Golf plug-in hybrid concept in 2010 |publisher=Autoblog.com |date=26 June 2008 |accessdate=1 November 2010}} The combined power is {{convert|174|PS|kW|order=flip|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://jalopnik.com/397242/vw-golf-twin-drive-plug+in-hybrid-diesel-makes-prius-look-thirsty |title=VW Golf Twin Drive Plug-In Hybrid Diesel Makes Prius Look Thirsty |publisher=Jalopnik.com |date=26 June 2008 |accessdate=1 November 2010}} Volkswagen developed the Twin Drive system with eight German partners, and is planning a trial fleet of 20 Golfs outfitted with the system in 2010. The production version was expected to be based on new Mk6 Golf, featuring a 1.5 L turbodiesel engine and electric motor, with estimated arrival date of 2015.{{cite web|last=Vijayenthiran |first=Viknesh |url=http://www.motorauthority.com/volkswagen-twin-drive-plug-in-hybrids-not-due-until-2015.html |title=VW Twin Drive plug-in hybrids not due until 2015 |publisher=Motorauthority.com |date=4 September 2008 |accessdate=1 November 2010}} ==Golf GTI "Wörthersee 09" (2009)== The Golf GTI "Wörthersee 09" is a concept car based on the Golf GTI. 2.0-liter TSI. Its engine is rated at {{convert|211|PS|kW bhp|order=flip|abbr=on}}, with a 0–100 km/h (0-62 mph) acceleration time of 6.9 seconds and a top speed of {{convert|238|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}}. It features a Firespark Metallic red body color with GTI stripes, high-gloss black 19-inch alloy spoke wheels, smoked [[LED]] taillights, a lowered chassis and a new sport exhaust. Changes to the interior include aluminum tread plates, brushed aluminum trim and glossy black painted frames around the air vents, red bordered floor mats and black Nappa leather sport seats with red accents and "Berry White" leather piping. The vehicle was unveiled at the ''Wörthersee GTi-Treffen'' meet in [[Wörthersee]], Austria.{{cite web|last=Nunez |first=Alex |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2009/05/20/seeing-red-vw-unveils-gti-and-polo-worthersee-09-concepts/ |title=Seeing Red: VW unveils GTI and Polo Wörthersee '09 concepts |publisher=Autoblog.com |date=20 May 2009 |accessdate=1 November 2010}} == Golf R == [[File:VW Golf VI R Candyweiß.JPG|thumb|VW Golf VI R 3-door]] [[File:2008-2012 Volkswagen Golf (5K) R 5-door hatchback (2018-09-28) 02.jpg|thumb|right|VW Golf VI R 5-door]] There was much speculation about this vehicle, with uncertainty surrounding its name. Golf R20 was the most common name used prior to the Frankfurt Motor Show.{{cite web|last=Shunk |first=Chris |url=http://www.autoblog.com/2009/09/14/frankfurt-preview-volkswagen-r20-hits-the-web-early/ |title=Frankfurt Preview: Volkswagen R20 hits the web early |publisher=Autoblog.com |date=14 September 2009 |accessdate=1 November 2010}} Once finally unveiled by Volkswagen at the Frankfurt IAA, on 15 September 2009, it was confirmed the R32 replacement would simply be called the Golf R.{{cite web|url=http://www.ausmotive.com/2009/09/15/volkswagen-golf-r.html |title=Frankfurt: Volkswagen Golf R |publisher=AUSmotive.com |date= |accessdate=1 November 2010}} The Golf R is powered by a {{convert|1984|cc|L CID|1|abbr=on}} [[Gasoline direct injection|FSI]] [[turbocharged]] [[Inline-four engine]] that produces {{Convert|270|PS|bhp kW|0|abbr=on}} at 6000 rpm and {{Convert|350|Nm|lbft|0|abbr=on}} at 2500-5000 rpm of [[Torque#Machine torque|torque]]. VW claims the car can get from 0–{{cvt|100|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}} in 5.5 seconds for [[Direct-shift gearbox|DSG]] equipped models, or 5.7 seconds for cars fitted with a [[manual transmission]].{{cite web|url=https://www.carfolio.com/specifications/models/car/?car=207592|website=carfolio.com|title=2009 Volkswagen Golf R Golf 6|accessdate=June 29, 2018}} The Golf R features these main upgrades over the standard FSI [[List of Volkswagen Group petrol engines#2.0 R4 16v "Turbo FSI"/TSI/TFSI (EA113)|EA113 engine]]: * Lower compression forged pistons * Strengthened connecting rods * Enlarged wrist pins * Stronger piston rings * Upgraded bearings * Reinforced engine block * Upgraded camshafts (longer duration) * Upgraded injectors (+13% flow) * Larger K04 turbo producing 1.2 bar of boost (+3 PSI over K03 equipped GTI) * Larger intercooler (+30%) * Relocated bypass valve The Golf R employs a familiar, but revised (5th-generation) Haldex 4motion all-wheel drive system. The Golf R has many similar styling traits to its Scirocco R sibling and is the first Golf to have LED rear tail lights factory fitted. In Australia, Japan, China, America and South Africa the '''Golf R engine''' is detuned to suit hotter climate conditions. It is detuned from {{Convert|199|kW|PS bhp|0|abbr=on}} to {{Convert|188|kW|PS bhp|0|abbr=on}} and {{Convert|350|Nm|lb·ft|abbr=on}} to {{Convert|330|Nm|lb·ft|abbr=on}}. On 9 December 2010, Volkswagen announced that the Golf R will be available in the United States beginning in 2012. Both two- and four-door versions were offered, and the DSG transmission was not an option.{{cite web |url=http://wot.motortrend.com/6735621/future/r-is-go-volkswagen-golf-r-coming-to-america-in-2012/index.html |title=R is Go: Volkswagen Golf R Coming to America in 2012}} The US version Golf R features a slightly detuned engine producing {{Convert|256|HP|kW|order=flip|abbr=on}} and {{Convert|243|lb·ft|Nm|abbr=on}}. On 14 December 2010, Volkswagen announced that the Golf R will be available in Canada beginning in "early" 2012. Only a four-door version with six-speed manual transmission was offered. Four colours of the GTI were offered plus the R-exclusive "Rising Blue". All options were standard including navigation, sun roof, leather interior, and "Kessy" keyless entry.{{cite web|url=http://www.georgetownvw.com/BuildAndPrice/DDP5.aspx?lng=2 |title=2012 Golf R – Confirmed! – Georgetowan Volkswagen |publisher=Georgetownvw.com |date=14 December 2010 |accessdate=29 May 2011}} The North American versions shipped with incandescent tail lights, identical to the tail lights found on the GTI, instead of the LED tail lights used in the rest of the world. ==Special editions== ===GTI Edition 35=== Following Volkswagen's successful 30th anniversary edition GTI , Volkswagen marked the GTI's 35th anniversary by producing the '''GTI Edition 35'''. The Edition 35 runs an evolution of the Mk5 GTI engine that is also used in the Golf R (see above) but with a reduced boost level to 13psi max (0.9bar), running a K04 turbocharger, enabling its power levels to fit just above the standard Mk6 GTI (which runs a EA888 TSI engine) , but below the Golf R. The engine has more in common with the Mk5 Edition [[Volkswagen Golf Mk5#GTI Edition 30|30]], Mk5 Pirelli Edition and Mk6 R than the standard Mk6 GTI Standard fit items to differentiate this model were : *engine power was up 25bhp from the standard (TSI) GTI to 232bhp using an evolution of the EA111 engine * black gloss wing mirrors * gloss black front splitter (oddly the rear is a standard GTI non painted affair) * side skirts from the R * 18in 'Watkins Glen' alloys (with a 19in 'Glendale' option) * depending on the 'market' the interior options were ‘35’ embroidered tartan seats, leather 'GTI' logo (standard and only option for UK market) or '35' part leather seats * honeycomb dash inserts * retro golf ball-style gear lever * '35' chrome scripting on the front wings * '35' door kick plates ==International markets== {{Multiple image | align = left | direction = vertical | width = | image1 = VW Golf VI GTI front 20090408.jpg | image2 = VW Golf VI GTI rear 20090408.jpg | caption2 = Volkswagen GTI 3-door, Europe }} In the United States and Canada, the car was sold as the Volkswagen Golf when it arrived in showrooms in October 2009, dropping the "Rabbit" badge that was used for the Golf Mk5.{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwire.com/press-release/Volkswagen-Canada-1049426.html |title=Volkswagen Canada |publisher=Marketwire.com |date=23 September 2009 |accessdate=1 November 2010}} The wagon, a restyled version of the Mk5 and the only Golf model made in Mexico, is sold in Canada as "Golf Wagon", but in the United States retains the "Jetta SportWagen" designation (while wearing Golf front sheetmetal). North American Golfs will carry over the same engines as the Mk5 (the same 2.5L [[Straight-five engine|five-cylinder]] from the Mk5, the 2.0TDI and the 2.0T) and, while the GTI and TDI continue to offer the six-speed [[manual transmission]], the 2.5 L will re-use the five-speed manual ([[Automatic transmission|automatic]] will be a six-speed tiptronic). The new Golf is also available in Mexico but for the time being only in the wagon configuration that is marketed as Golf SportWagen that became available in early October replacing the Bora Sportwagen with the new Golf's front end. {{Multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 200 | image1 = VW Golf 1.4 TSI Team (VI) – Heckansicht, 26. März 2011, Ratingen.jpg | caption1 = Volkswagen Golf 1.4 TSI Team, Germany | image2 = 2009-2012 Volkswagen Golf (5K) 118TSI Comfortline 5-door hatchback (2018-11-02) 02.jpg | caption2 = Volkswagen Golf 118TSI Comfortline, Australia | image3 = VWGolf6Int.jpg | caption3 = Interior }} The Australian public got their first taste of the new Mk6 at the [[Melbourne International Motor Show]], which began on 27 February 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.ausmotive.com/2009/01/22/golf-vi-to-be-launched-at-melbourne-international-motor-show.html |title=Golf VI to be launched at Melbourne International Motor Show |publisher=AUSmotive.com |date= |accessdate=1 November 2010}} The new Golf was launched around the country at the same time. The Mk6 GTI went on sale from 30 October 2009.[http://www.volkswagen.com.au/etc/medialib/vwcms/virtualmaster/en_au/company/news.Par.0022.File.pdf/new_golf_gti_launch.pdf]{{dead link|date=May 2011}} On 19 January 2010 the Golf was awarded the 2009 Wheels Car of the Year title, which is acknowledged as the country's most prestigious car award.{{cite web|url=http://www.ausmotive.com/2010/01/19/volkswagen-golf-wins-wheels-coty.html |title=Volkswagen Golf wins Wheels COTY |publisher=AUSmotive.com |date= |accessdate=1 November 2010}} It was the first time the Golf had been awarded the title since 1976. VW Australia launched the new base model golf with 1.2-litre engine same as the new Polo in September 2010 and went on sale in 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.themotorreport.com.au/50893/volkswagen-golf-77tsi-coming-to-australia-as-new-entry-level-model |title=Volkswagen Golf 77TSI Launched In Australia |date=28 September 2010 |website=www.themotorreport.com.au}} In South Africa the new Mk6 Golf went on sale in April 2009. The South African version of the GTI went on sale in July 2009. In Japan the new Mk6 Golf went on sale in April 2009. The Japanese version of the GTI went on sale in August 2009. In China, the Golf Mk6 is made by [[FAW-VW]], and in March 2010 the GTI begins to be built locally. It is the first time the GTI is built in China. The Chinese-Spec Golf GTI uses a different engine than the international one, a 2.0 TSI which produces only {{Convert|200|hp|kW|order=flip|abbr=on}}, {{Convert|10|hp|kW|order=flip|abbr=on}} less than the original one. This engine is also used by the [[VW Magotan]]. In Mexico, the only two versions available until August 2011 were the German-imported 3-door GTI in both 6-speed manual and 6-speed DSG transmissions, and the Mexican-produced Golf SportWagen with a 170 bhp 2.5 L inline 5-cylinder with a 6-speed Tiptronic transmission. In September 2012, a 5-door version in Comfortline trim, with 1.4 L TSI engine with 177 hp and 6-speed manual gearbox imported from Germany was added. Since the end of production is imminent, it will be limited to 4,000 units. In Chile, the Golf Mk6 was presented in October 2010 at the XI Salón del Automóvil de Santiago, starting sales immediately. Chile is the first country in South America to sell the Mk6, as a restyled version of the Mk4 is still in production in Brazil for Latin America. The Mk6 is available in Chile with the 1.6 L Petrol engine (101 hp) both in five-speed manual and seven-speed [[Direct-Shift Gearbox|DSG]] transmissions. In India, the Golf Mk6 was rumored to be introduced in 2011 but in a recent interview, Volkswagen Chief Executive Officer said that the plans for introducing a Golf have been suspended,{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} to preserve the success of VW Vento in the Indian market. The Golf, if released, would be similarly priced as the Vento and VW does not want Vento sales to slip. He also stated they may bring in a more localized Golf with the same engine choices as the Vento when numbers stabilize in the near future. ==Motorsport== In [[auto racing]], [[Audi Performance and Racing|APR Motorsport]] has led two MKVI VW GTIs to victory in the Grand-Am [[Continental Tire Sports Car Challenge]] Street Tuner (ST) class.Grand-Am.com [https://web.archive.org/web/20110929114508/http://www.grand-am.com/schedule/results.cfm?series=k&eid=882 TheGlen.com 200 Results]Grand-Am.com [https://web.archive.org/web/20110929114532/http://www.grand-am.com/schedule/results.cfm?series=k&eid=883 EMCO Gears Classic - Split Classes Results]Grand-Am.com [https://web.archive.org/web/20110929114550/http://www.grand-am.com/schedule/results.cfm?series=k&eid=884&sid=527 Legacy Credit Union 200 Results]Grand-Am.com [http://www.grand-am.com/schedule/results.cfm?series=k&eid=886 Legacy Credit Union 200 Results] To commemorate the 35th Anniversary of the Golf GTI, [[Volkswagen Motorsport]] entered the 2011 [[24 Hours Nürburgring]] with the "Golf24". This Golf was equipped with a 2,500 cc five-cylinder turbo engine with 324 kW (440 PS) and 540 Nm, permanent 4WD and a sequential six-speed gearbox.{{cite web |author=Volkswagen Motorsport |url=http://www.volkswagen-motorsport.com/web/news/index.php?&flash=no&lg=d&st=355&op=id& |title=Comeback in der "Grünen Hölle" |publisher=Volkswagen Motorsport |date= |accessdate=29 May 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317182528/http://www.volkswagen-motorsport.com/web/news/index.php?&flash=no&lg=d&st=355&op=id& |archive-date=17 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} In the third [[Veranstaltergemeinschaft Langstreckenpokal Nürburgring|VLN]] race of 2011, the Golf24 finished sixth overall, with its best lap only nine seconds slower than the fastest race lap, which was clocked by a Ferrari 458. For the 24 Hours, the team hoped for rain, and jokingly considered wetting the track by [[aerial firefighting]].http://adac.24h-rennen.de/Artikel.452.0.html?&tx_ttnews {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726232339/http://adac.24h-rennen.de/Artikel.452.0.html?&tx_ttnews |date=26 July 2011 }}[tt_news]=5860&cHash=bd9cd9aa93 Eventually, though, neither of the three Golf24s finished the race, with one of them suffering a pit-entry accident and another blowing a gearbox. When the gearbox of the remaining Golf24 started overheating, VW decided to retire it to find out the cause of the gearbox trouble. ==Awards== * 2009 [[World Car of the Year]] {{cite [[File:Shefler Cooker JNV school Leh-Ladakh.JPG|thumb|Scheffler cooker at JNV school in [[Leh]], India.]] '''Wolfgang Scheffler''' (born 1956) is the inventor/promoter of Scheffler Reflectors, large, flexible parabolic reflecting dishes that concentrate sunlight for [[solar cooking]] in community kitchens, bakeries, and in the world's first solar-powered [[crematorium]].<ref>http://www.solare-bruecke.org/infoartikel/Papers_%20from_SCI_Conference_2006/22_wolfgang_scheffler.pdf</ref> By early 2008, over 2000 <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rebootnow.org/speakers/wolfgangandhelke.shtml |title=Reboot Now Sustainability Conference Workshop with Wolfgang Scheffler & Heike Hoedt<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2008-04-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408111312/http://www.rebootnow.org/speakers/wolfgangandhelke.shtml |archive-date=2008-04-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> large cookers of his design had been built distributed worldwide including the world's largest solar cooker.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.unesco.or.kr/kor/activity2004/data/sn200407_Gadhia.doc | title = Environmental and Economic Impacts of Solar Heat Cookers | publisher = UNESCO | accessdate = 2008-04-08 | quote = Finances for the approximately Rs 25 lakh project came from the German Society for Technological Cooperation (GTZ; Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit). }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
Schaeffler was born in [[Innsbruck]], [[Austria]], and received the Special Recognition Award at the 2006 [[Nuclear-Free Future Award]],<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nuclear-free.com/english/scheffler.htm |title=Wolfgang Scheffler and Heide Hoedt, 2006 Nuclear-Free Future Solutions Award<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2008-04-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080807114352/http://www.nuclear-free.com/english/scheffler.htm |archive-date=2008-08-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
